And then scrape it off, and wash it out thoroughly according to whatever disposition you find possible for it, and with whatever wit is right for you: when it does not make a contrary Vein or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that there are many tools and saws for cutting these bones, depending on the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness and fineness, and their size and purity, and their hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare an instrument suitable for all kinds of operations.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations require a long study when you are holding the instrument in your hand.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And understanding the methods of this art will be a witness to the methods of diseases: then you will already find, through yourself, what is suitable for him from instruments, for every disease.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you, at the end of this chapter, the number of instruments, which you place as examples over what you cut, and proof of what you experience on others.
Forma Serrae.	The shape of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of a different saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of a different saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the saw, drawn out slightly to one side.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its bow be made higher, its sharpness from iron: and its handle from beech, and let it be made with a slightly off-center pyramid.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The shape of the razor, joined together.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be shaped according to the form of a star-shaped claw: and its edges be shaped according to the form of dots made by the elephant's foot.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable unless they are joined with heads of razor blades, when they become dull, or a wide and large mouth; and its width is great.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The shape of a larger razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The shape of a medium-sized razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Shape of the blade-edge.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The shape is concave.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The shape of the other edge is thin.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape of the other edge is curved at its end.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The blade shape is thin and delicate.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape of the blade with which bones are incised.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape of the other large blade.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a radio and the end is like a saw: it is exhibited in many places from the incision of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of the blade that corresponds to its incision which has been made through the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular, and its ends are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	It fits from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And likewise it is necessary that all which we have said of the blades, and incisions, and saws, should be.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Regarding the incising of bones and the sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The ends putrify, or for an extrinsic cause, or an intrinsic one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	But when the patient was cured by the application of medicines, and there is no cure for the corruption: and you see that corruption incises in the limb, where it does not give any sign: then you should cut into that limb as far as the place where the corruption follows, so that the patient may be saved by that limb from death, or from a greater defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign where that takes place is that the limb is discolored until it is cured: that fire burns it, or it putsrefies after nigridine: until it incises putrefaction as far as that limb which follows it, and it seizes in the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Thus when there is proper incising with it, and likewise if the cause of corruption is from some percussion of certain venenosos: such as the marine scorpion, and the horse-fly, and the gnat, and others.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore corruption, or percussion is in the end of a finger, then cut that finger, and do not allow space for corruption to spread, so that it incises as far as the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root quickly, and do not leave space for corruption, until it reaches the powerful arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it has entered into it, then cut the arm at the shoulder joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption has passed and you see it around the hip: then death is certain in that place.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And besides this cure, there is a quantity of strength.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise do with the foot, when corruption enters into a toe, then cut it at the joint: and if it enters into the shoe, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it has risen up to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	What if corruption has already reached above the knee, there is no remedy except to amputate and leave the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to cut a member off, or to bend it, is so that you tense the ligaments below, which you wish to cut: and tense another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one minister of the ligaments extend to the lower: and let another minister of the ligaments extend upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you shall separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a chisel, until all the flesh is seen.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut it, or bend it.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And you shall place a sheet of linen before all the parts, so that the saw does not touch the sound place: and let happen to the sick person an addition of scar, and of swollen heat.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if blood comes out from within while you are working, then quickly causticate the place: or put on some powder to stop the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then go back to your own medicine, until it is finished.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded member with a suitable ligament, and take care of it, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this same thing that I told you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	What is, because it happened in his black foot, when the ash that is absorbed is like the combustion of fire; and that corruption first happened in his finger, until he began his whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Then the man recovered from his swelling, after he saw the corruption enter into his limb with its pain, which he felt and its dryness; and it entered himself at the joint, and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after he had passed a long time, that corruption again happened to him in the same way in his finger of his right hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I tried to recover that superfluity with him when I put on the hand with the medicines after the purification of his body: and the superfluity did not respond, and began to enter into another finger; until it began corruption in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me then to cut his hand off: and I would not do it, hoping from me about the response of that superfluity: and I was afraid also about him at the cutting off of his hand death.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the strength of the man was over his falling.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Then when he was disappointed from me, he returned to his land: and came to me about it, for he desired to recover, and cut off all his hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this story, except that it might be a help about what falls of this kind of disease: and that it might show, according to when it happens.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Of the cure of sores, and the quality of clogging with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 80.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When it happens that a sore is on some fleshy member, and its space is prolonged, until it forms a clump of pus: then it breaks, or pierces, and what is in it is discharged out, leaving behind an empty place like a wound, and the skin over it as thin fabric: and does not spread to the final corruption of its disease, nor prints into the mouth, nor the nerves, nor the ligaments: it deserves to be called a sore: but if it prolongs its space, until it impresses the corruption on some of these members, then it is called a fistula, or a tubercle.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And his cure is that you should strike off the whole skin as it peelings: and above all when it has thinned, and made like a cloth: and trust that it will not stick to the place because of its decay.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and not lead to such corruption: and if there is a thickness of flesh on it, then your cure with Clister is this: and it is as if you consider it towards the Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is discharged from it has a foul odor: then your cure with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and myrrh, parts equal, gathered together in a jar: and boiled over fire, until it turns red with the medicine: and comes to a thickness like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it whatever you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and your cure with Clister put in it: and tightly close the opening, and let the medicine flow into it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with an expression: do this for days, until the sinuses are cleared and the foul odor is gone away.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when your cure is made with water of ash, when this medicine is not present with you: and it is as if you take the ash of oak wood, or the ash from oak trees: and throw it on the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then stir it, and your cure with it, until you trust that the sinuses are now washed away.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	That if the tolerance to Egyptian medicine or water of ash is not good, then your cure with water and honey, in which there is also some crushed myrrh.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or your cure with honey and wine mixed, because of the property of honey is to cleanse and wash away: and the wine makes the sinuses adhere, especially when there is an abundance of astringency and dryness.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	How often you do that and be confident that the corruption of the sinus is now far away: then let him make him a clister with what he does, to give birth to flesh in him.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And is, so that you take from the plaster dyafinicon: and dissolve him with olive oil, and wine stypical: or let him make himself a clister with some medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise of ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the orifice of the sinus is strict, in which the cannula of the clister does not enter: then increase it with iron a little: or put in him licorium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, or in unguento basilicon, until it is increased.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And likewise if the orifice is also wide, then aggregate the lips with a suture: and let him go out of it a quantity in which to be added to the clister without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And likewise if the orifice from which the pus runs is raised higher: then dry him in a lower place that is in him, so that the pus runs out of it down: for when the pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being generated in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	That if you do not find it possible to dry the sinus all around lower than it is, according to what you want: then strive, so that you prepare the member with which the pus runs out of it with ease according to which you prepare it for yourself.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Strive, so that nothing of the pus remains in it at all: and take medicines consolidatıves which are placed on the mark, fitting for what you want.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And have a cloth of such a quantity that it comes into contact with all of the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps in the direct orifice of the sinus hole, a little wider orifice of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the ointment with soft brushes over another cloth according to the quantity of the hole: and put it on him in a position distant from the orifice of the sinus, so that the exit of the pus is facilitated: and do not remove the large cloth, unless after some days take off one edge.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But he who is above the sinus opening, that is whom you move at all times, so that he emerges from it what is gathered in him from pus; and so that you know, that which runs out of it virus, is much or little: or digested or indigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this again consider the place of the sinus itself, that does the lord feel pain or not be in it pain, and if it is in it a swelling or not be in it a swelling.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	Now when your medication is extended thus, and you see the material that emerges above the sinus opening, then know that the sinus has already adhering, or is approaching adhesion of the scar; then therefore solve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth to another, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if it emerges from the sinus after a long interval subtile virus, then do not despair of the adhesion of it, because the cure of it approaches, because there are people who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and among them are those who act in the opposite way to it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it emerges from the sinus after many days pus undigested, then know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its duration is prolonged: then add to the drying of medicines, truly let the doctors make them so that they are in their substance humid, and in their virtue dry: like the unguent of daphnicum, when it is added to it in abundance of addition from zeki.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And at the very last when it is cured, that you take the unguent of daphnicum, and dissolve it with rose oil, and rub it on the old wound to equal substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then prepare the wound with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And this same action does, when you do not have present to you the unguent of daphnicum, honey, when you heat it up, until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh and aloe and incense; let them all be mixed together and powder and spread it on honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then bind the cloth over the wound and tie it around the sinew: and bind the cloth with the honey you have prepared until it thickens: and sprinkle the powder on the wound, and bind it to the cloth, and tie it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes when it is administered in him long aristolochia, and roots of lily of the sky, and there is a lily: and flour of grass, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple, or mixed, knead it, and sift the powder over the honey you have prepared, and use that.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	That if the matter of the sinew is prolonged, and does not heal with this cure: then you shall know that there is corruption in it: or it already has made an impression on the bones, or on the other hard members, or ligaments: then cure that member with fistulas, according to what has been said.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the cure of a finger that is swollen and rubbed with ointment, and an incision in the finger added, and cutting it off.
Caput XCI.	Chapter LXI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritium is an inflammation that arises under the nail of the thumb or of any other finger.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore the matter of it is prolonged, and neglected in its cure, and turns into an abscess that discharges pus, until it corrupts the nail root: and perhaps corrupts all of it, and perhaps reaches the jaw, until there is a foul odor from it: and makes the end of the finger swollen, and blackens its color.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you cure that member with the method we have mentioned above, and your cure does not succeed: then you must cut away all the excess that remains under the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the finger after it.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Because the cauterization of the injured is very hot.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if the jaw is sound, and the nail also is healthy, and the addition of the nail begins to press on the flesh toward the inside, and begins to prick it, then you should place a very fine lead under the corner of the nail that pricks the flesh, and push it up: and cut the flesh easily, and place over it what remains of the flesh from burning medicines, and corrosives, until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then this cure with the ointment, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if the corruption has already set deep into the bone, then it is necessary that you break that bone and take it out: for it does not heal at all while it remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the corruption and the corrosion penetrating into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to what was said above as a reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then heal that person, until he heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	But if there is a pain due to the fingernail being torn or struck; and it begins to ache acutely, then first of all you should drain the blood from the wound.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatula, cutting across from above to the nail.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard it, so that the cut does not reach the flesh under the nail; for you will bring about an extremely painful pain in him, and it will be a cause of birth of flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then heal the place with this while he sits; for he will suffer from great pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger, however, that is added on some of the hands of men, perhaps is all flesh; and perhaps there are bones in it, and perhaps there is a nail on it; and perhaps its birth is in the joint of the hand or in any other part of it.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	This one who is born in some joints of the fingers does not move; and this one who is born near to the joint of the finger may be moved.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	But this flesh that is added on some of them is easily cut.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, to cut it with a flat spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the healing of that one whose birth is in the joint of the hand is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	So then, abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in that one who is born in the finger up to its last joint, then it is necessary that you cut off its first flesh with a round knife up to the nail.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then cut the bone with one of those saws suitable for cutting bones to that end.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the fusion that occurs between the fingers often happens many times, or from birth in man, that is, he is born with it, or from bone injury, or fireburn, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to separate this fusion, until the fingers recover their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a piece of lindenwood or cloth dipped in rosin oil: so that they do not quickly heal and separate them: or place between them a thin lead plate, until the place heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise, if the fusion occurs in some of the fingers with the palm, then dry out that fusion, according to how it is prepared and suitable for the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Regarding the Incision: The fault is not in those who translate, but in those who are unable
Caput XCII.	Chapter LII. On Wounds
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins that are swollen, large, and full of melancholy fluid occur in many parts of the body; and most often they occur in the legs, especially in those who walk or work a lot, or who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to provide strong treatment with some form of incisions and drainage for the body from black cholera.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then, draw blood from the patient with a basin-shaped cup.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of these wounds with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they should rest, and the black blood should be drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that a vein should be raised, and all the blood should be drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	But the incising of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Whip the leg first with hot water a lot, until the thick, putrid blood is dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the leg tightly by the nurse from the upper part of the hip to the lower part of the knee with strips, and tie it up with strips.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the wound in one, two, or three sections with a wide piece of cloth.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then wash, that is, wipe away the blood from the lower part of the leg with your hand until it reaches the top and from the upper part let it run into the bowl; because the sick should first be bled from above.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the wound with a cloth down to below; until he has gone out of the blood as much as you see is sufficient and what the strength of the sick bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it up; and order him not to have any food that generates black bile: and again let there be an evacuation and a bleeding when the veins are filled, and this pain the sick man.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	But the elevation is to be made in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the leg of the sick if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then put him into a bath: or wrap him up in the leg with warm water until it turns red, and the veins swell; or he exercises strongly if there is no bath present, until he warms the limb.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in one straight piece of cloth along the length of it; or at the end of it near the knee, or in the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook and scrape away the wound from every part, until you can feel it; and that is the appearance of it, which you see turns red into blackness by its falling.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	But when you have taken off the skin, you will see it white as a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then put beneath it a razor, until when it is washed away and has gone out from the skin: hang it up with a blind hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another piece of cloth close to that piece of cloth with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin off from the upper part of the leg, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then wash it with razors as you have done, and hang it up with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then cut off another section, or multiple sections, if you are able to.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then wipe it clean, and make the incision at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove it to the section above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And make that, until you remove it from the upper section, or higher sections, until it is completely removed: then make the incision.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not obey you when you try to remove and clean it: then insert a strong double thread into it, and tie it, and remove it: or insert Radium under it: and withdraw your hand from all parts until it is removed.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful, so that it does not get cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to remove it deeply, and it will enter into the sick part, causing harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you completely remove it: then place it on the spot that is sore, soaked in wine and oil, or just oil: and care for it, until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	Which if it is contracted, having a curvature to which there is an angle of inclination, and not as we said according to the straight line: then you must find out over all its parts, and the locations of its contraction.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it with a hook, until you clean it all over: and be careful at the section above your hook, so that you do not cut yourself on it, or make yourself sore: for it will be difficult to clean you if you hang it on you, or remove it from you.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	So then be careful with your caution.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The shape of the wound when the wine heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of the hook.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not a curvature like the rest of the hook, and there is no acute extremity, so it does not sore the skin: and it has a blunt flexibility, gentle: for if it were subtle, it would cut the skin with its subtlety: but it has excess thickness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the venous blood from the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter LIII on the Head.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is found in the legs on warm ground, such as in Al-Jaziya and Arabia, and on dry, hot ground with little vegetation, that is, where no herbs or trees grow.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And indeed its origin is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just as it happens within the bodies of snakes and worms, and how vermin are generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the inception of this vein is a severe inflammation in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the area becomes swollen.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to emerge from the area of swelling, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When this end of it appears, then you should wrap a piece of lead around it, whose weight is from two to three drachmas, up to five drachmas, and fix it in place: and remove the lead from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	As often as anything moves out of it towards the outside, wrap it in lead and mark it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged for a long time, then cut off a portion of it, and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut off its root until it has completely emerged.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut into it, it will contract and penetrate into the flesh; and it causes pustules to form, putrefaction in the place, and a bad sore.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently, and extracted slowly, until it has completely emerged from its root, and nothing of it remains in the body: and this vein emerges from certain people at a length of five palms and ten fingers.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And it has reached me, for it has emerged from a man of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if you are injured during your treatment: then insert a ray into its openings and pierce it with the ray, with the body, until all that is inside it has drained out of it, and administer decay to the site with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then the care of him is to cure the sores.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And these [veins] sometimes have many branches, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and many openings are present in it, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore care for him, as we have said in the division, and with what has been stated above.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Regarding the section on worms that are born under the skin, and it is called a sore plague.
Caput XCIIII.	Head 84.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This plague is called in some country with us a sore plague: because it often happens that worms are born, and there is one only sore spot which appears between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it moves in the whole body, ascending and descending, and is felt through sensation when it walks with its limbs, until it stops wherever it stops in the skin, and it goes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the decay of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happen worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are afraid of its malignity.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it moves in the body, and goes up to the head, and reaches a spot: then perhaps it opens in that place, and goes out, and destroys an eye; and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	But when you are to care for him, and to take him out, then he does not do that unless it walks with its limbs, and feels the sensation with its sight.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, so that you tie what is above him, and what is under him with a strong knot.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry up on top of him, and take him out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it penetrates into the flesh and does not affect him: then place cautery over the spot with fire until he dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater is what is feared, that is corruption of it, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see it already reaching to the head near the eye, then tighten below it a good tight bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over him, and remove him.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that he should use his own purification, with medicines solving the bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	[On sectioning over sickness by Al-Nakhi].
Caput XCV.	Chapter 105.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This sickness is called in our language Nakir, and it is a pain that occurs in some member; then it passes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have already seen it, according as I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she raised her arm and I saw an inflamed swelling in the armpit.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw one swelling going up with a fire-like heat, as if it were skin, rising faster than it can be: like silver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Then the pain receded from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then after an hour he sat down, and ran through the rest of his body, until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that it was running all over his whole body, according as I saw it.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its passing from one member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself did not see this sickness with my eyes before in such a way according to this mode.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I saw many who suffered from the passing of pain from one member to another; and I did not see it with my eyes, as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not think that it is, unless because she was one of those who came from the wombs of dried-up bodies whose venes were detected: hence this appears to the sense as a change in windiness.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear in this way in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, hiding the veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you are treating her and the patient feels that pain, then if it appears to you with your eye as we have said, then hold it above her, and under her quickly: and dry above her, until she comes out this windiness: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see the vein with your eyes: then care for the vein with the scraping of the body, and with that which drives out windiness, and makes them red with bitter pills, and with pills of serapeum, and similar ones.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the Extraction of Arrowheads.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter LXVI. On the Extraction of Arrowheads.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their species and according to the places in which they are lodged in the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	But there is a difference between them, because there are some that have large points, and small: and埋伏、埋伏し、隠れ潜り
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these there are three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And of these some are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And of these some are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	But those that lodge in the limbs, fall in two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or limbs are from the principal limbs, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and those similar to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When then falls into any of these limbs, and you see signs of death, which I will tell you about later, then it is necessary to remove the arrow from among them, for death follows it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not buried deep within the limb, then extract it, and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the arrow falls into the brain and pierces bone and exits through a hole that is above the brain, then occur: for there occur from it violent sodomy, scotoma, vertigo, redness in the eyes, inflammation, redness in the tongue, spasms, confusion of thought, and cholera-like nausea.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out through the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is lost, and speech is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And white pus comes out of the wound's site like mucus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And exits from it similar to a water-like flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	But if these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and pull out the arrow if it has not already exited.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that has hit the heart are: it is near the left nipple: and it feels as if it were almost fixed to a hard thing, not to a soft thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow moves with a similar motion to a pulse: and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows that extreme coldness of the limbs, and cold sweat, and fainting spells.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	So you know, death has clearly descended.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow that hits the lung is the exit of foamy blood from the wound: and the veins that run along the neck, begin to pulse, and their color changes with the pulse.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out a great, deep breath: and seeks the cool air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	That if an arrow hits the spine, which is in the chest: then it is close to a few ribs: and it becomes a great sigh with violent pain, with a sigh: and the shoulders' muscles all move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow hits the stomach, then perhaps it exits through the mouth from undigested food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow hits the belly and gets stuck there: it exits through the wound with stool, or dung, or already broken intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope for his recovery or for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	For if the arrow falls into the bladder and urine is discharged, and something comes out to the outside, and the pain is stronger on the sick person, then you should know that it is a fatal wound.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, tongue, jaw, back ribs, shoulders, hips, legs, and their corresponding bones, should be tended to according to a number of dispositions. Unless the arrow hits an artery or nerve, and then it is not a mortal wound.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I will tell you that I saw such arrows, which indicates to you the hope for your recovery.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	For an arrow fell into a man's eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it from him on the other side, with fat from his ear: and he was healed, and there was no damage to his eye from the arrow.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen into his eye underneath his eyebrow; and the arrow was now hidden, and I could not extract it unless I cut off part of his cheekbone, where it stuck in its own wood: and it was a large arrow among the arrows of the Turks, with a soft iron point, where there were no blades.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was healed, and there was no misfortune to his eye from the arrow.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow, and that one had blades.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed it with two fingers: and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	So I took care of it carefully until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow that had fallen into the man's belly; and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After he had been there thirty days and nothing was changed in his condition with regard to the dispositions, I followed him along the line of the bow: and as for his intellect, I took it out from him; and he recovered, and no misfortune befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man who had been struck in the back by an arrow, and the fracture was healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After he had been seven years out, the arrow came out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow had fallen into the belly, and the fracture was healed over it, and the arrow remained within her; and nothing was changed in her condition with regard to any of her natural dispositions, and no harm befell her in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen on the face, and the fracture was healed over it, and remained there, causing him little pain; and I saw many similar cases.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I took out an arrow from a king's son which had fallen on his nose and had sunk a little to the right side; and the arrow was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So they called me to cure him after the arrow's death for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Then I found the arrow's shaft quite tightly bound.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I asked him what it felt like and he said that he could feel a prick and pain on the right side of his face.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	Then I hoped that it might be the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	Then I applied a plaster where the drawing-in and digesting force was concentrated, trusting to me that the spot would become better; and it seemed to me as a sign of the arrow, which I should have struck on it: and no misfortune befell in that place as indicating that the arrow followed its course.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	So I applied the plaster to him for several days; and no misfortune befell him, and his fracture was healed over during that time: but he remained feeble from the extraction of it for a day or so, until he felt an arrow in his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	And I put an acute medicine on that wound and kept it open for many days, until the pain was gone; and when I tried to touch it, I felt a sharp pain in the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added more of the acute medicine to the wound, keeping it open for about four months; and then the tip of the arrow finally showed itself to us: And time passed with me as I continued to apply that acute medicine to the wound.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then, when the arrowhead had become larger and was possible for me to insert the hooks into it and move it, I did not cease to be subtle, and devised means with which to work on it; until one day I inserted a certain die with curved hooks in the end of the wound, according to the shape of their tips; then I pulled it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the arrow.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And some doctors say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Then I restored it, and the wound healed, whole and sound: nor did any harm come to him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you about the quality of extraction of some arrows: that you place a rule and meaning on it which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For since the parts of this art and the distinctions thereof are not understood with a narrative; neither does that book understand, and the skilled craftsman compares to little over much: and when something is present he understands it, and when something is absent he understands that too: and he discovers a new operation, and a new instrument for the descent of foreign things in this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say then that arrows do not come out from the body by their own power unless they have two types of motion.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from a place from which they entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or through the opposite side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, or is an arrow moving in a fleshly place; and is attracted, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If he does not comply with the exit within the hour in which it falls: then you must let go of him for a few days until his meat that is in his surroundings putrefies: and his attraction will be alleviated, and his egress.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if he is broken into bone, and does not comply with you to the exit, then let go of him also for a few days: and again let it out with attraction and movement every day until he emerges.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That if he does not comply with you to the exit after a few days, then you must perform in his circumference with a small blade, until the archers become larger.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If, however, the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has already gone into one of the brain vents, and a certain accident appears from those I have mentioned: then abstain from attracting the arrow, and let it go, until it is even with him after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the neck, then death does not prolong for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, unless it penetrates only into bone, and does not reach the neck: and remains weak for a few days, and nothing happens to him from those accidents: then use your wit in attracting the arrow and pulling it out.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is fixed firmly, and does not comply with you to the attraction: then apply a small blade around the arrow, as I have said: then care for the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow has already gone into hiding in the place of the body, and is hidden and concealed from your sense: then seek it out with trial.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If, however, you feel it, then attract it with some instruments that are suitable for attracting it.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you cannot get on top of it, because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in the depth: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor blood there: then find on top of it, until the bone grows larger, and it becomes possible to pull out the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If they have ears that need to be held, then I fix the free flesh on them from all sides with all the skill you can, and any tricks, if it cannot overcome the skin of the ears in a fracture, and their twisting, until it heals.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use your twisted hands with forceps to all parts until you make it heal: and the last subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and becomes difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot overcome it in one hour, then leave it for a few days, until what is around it putrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for indeed if the flow of blood makes you uncomfortable, then administer what we said in our chapter on cure: and protect your skill from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or chord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer any trick that you can make the arrow heal: and let it be with ease, and peace, or slowness, and strength, as I tell you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do when you pull out the arrow so that it is damaged according to the figure, according to what was with the injury of the arrow on itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more useful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If not, then administer what you can from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow that emerges from the opposite side, or has already gone out a little to the outside: or makes a bump at the tip of the arrow from the upper part of the skin next to it, and you see it standing out: then cut off over it, and let the section be according to the quantity it holds in it with forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract it: for indeed it is easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If, however, it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness, until it presses the arrow into the bone, and increases itself on it: and then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: discharge her for a few days; then examine her again until she walks out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If there is an arrow in her, then push it out with the wood.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if the arrow has penetrated and you want to give a push: then introduce a concaved tool into her behind the arrow's head: then push it out with the wood.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the arrow is concave: then push it out with an instrument that enters inside.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is relieved through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned: then let there be a concave meat, in which is venenum: if it is possible for you to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of her with him when he comes close to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling into the chest, or the abdomen, or the groin, and it is close to something that you can feel with your hand, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut it off, and carefully avoid cutting the flesh, or a nerve, and take it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then tighten the wound, if you see it, and take care of that, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the forceps, with which the arrows are removed.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The tips should be similar to a pencil, made like an iron: when they grip onto the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of them, large and small, medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow, and the depth of the wound, and the width of the wound, and the constriction.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the forceps is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the forceps is flat.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the end of the forceps like a ray, so that it can enter into the concave part of the arrow, and push it out with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This end of the forceps is concave like a feather, so that it can enter into the concave part of the arrow and push it out.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On phlebotomy of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter LVII on Phlebotomy
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins which the custom runs in the body and they are called:
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	The sixteen veins in the head are as follows: two pulsating veins, which lie behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries, which appear on either side of the face; and two veins that run from the two eyelids of the eyes, called the two aspirant veins; and a vein that runs across the middle of the forehead; and a vein at the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	The two jugulars which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And the two veins that run from the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And the two veins that run from the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are called the Algecirachian veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And the two veins that lie under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	But the veins that are phlebotomized in the arms are five in all.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the cephalic vein and it runs on the lateral side; and it is called the common vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the fuscal.
